column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent

#Text=DS : I interviewed a musician named John Vanderslice , and off-the-record he talked about how the mainstream music press has almost lost all influence -- Spin , Rolling Stone ; those kinds of magazines .
#Text=He said that whenever he did some small blog interview his web site jumped up in hits .
#Text=But when he got a favorable review in Rolling Stone he said , “ I barely heard a word about it . ”
#Text=JR :
#Text=The whole music industry has shifted over into networking sites , the Internet , and it 's just extremely comparable .
#Text=The way that it 's functioned -- and now half of the music industry is made up of this kind of independent record label -- that 's what 's happening with books .
#Text=You do n't have mid level artists recording at Sony , and you do n't have many mid-list authors at the large houses .
#Text=The little presses are snapping them up .

#Text=Of course , the large houses are aware of this , in the same way that the large record labels are aware of it , and I think that they 're gearing themselves to either take them over or have imprints address it .
#Text=Like , MTV Books now has Vice books .
#Text=They do like cool , beautiful books , and they 've given Vice a real platform to do what they want .
#Text=DS : Do you think it 's becoming like the pharmaceutical industry ?

#Text=There the really big drug companies do n't have a lot of drugs in the pipeline , but there are all these like little drug companies that are existing for one-or-two-drug clinical trials , and the big drug companies are watching them .
#Text=Once they have a seller , big pharma goes in and snaps up the little companies .
#Text=JR :
#Text=That 's exactly what it is .
#Text=I do n't know if it 's all bad , though .
#Text=When a big press buys a small press , the small press sort of loses its identity .
#Text=But it does n't happen right away .
#Text=Right now , the distribution of the small presses is so piss poor for the most part , that it 's just very hard for them to move units .
#Text=It 's a real challenge .
#Text=Most of them do n't care that much ; they want to have one or two books that are hits , but to sell big numbers of books , distribution is a real problem .
#Text=DS : How does the business model for small presses make up for a lack of blockbuster books ?
#Text=JR :
#Text=They need one or two , but most small presses that do n't care .
#Text=DS : It 's more of an idealistic enterprise , then ?
#Text=JR :
#Text=Yeah , if it 's a non-profit -- they get some grants .

#Text=For the functional small presses -- let 's say Akashic Books , or Archipelago Books -- which are very small but I believe run at a profit , the business model is to put all these books out there , and if one or two of them hits every couple of years , they 're fine .
#Text=Soft Skull
#Text=is another one .
#Text=I love MacAdam Cage ; I do n't know how they 're making any money , but they do wonderful books .
#Text=They 've got to have a few titles that sell a lot of copies .
#Text=One press who used to have this theory of publishing is Saint Martin 's Press , a sort of " Throw shit at the wall and see what sticks " phenomenon .
